0.text:
Pearson: This is the Friday, January 3, 2014
version of the Market Plus segment. Joining

5.text: us now is Elaine Kub. Elaine, welcome back.

8.text:
Pearson: One of the topics we didn't have
a chance to discuss during the full show was

12.text:
cotton. A little bit of a rally this week,
a bit of a sell of -- or last week -- a bit

16.text:
of a sell off this week. Where is the cotton
market headed?

18.text:
Kub: Well, that sell off this week that you
mentioned is fairly consistent with the general

23.text:
commodity pattern this week similar to crude
oil, something about coming into the New Year

27.text:
and traders wanted to lay off risk. And I
think there is significant risk in the cotton

31.text:
market right now. That uptrend that it has
been on was maybe tied to the tightness of

36.text:
the U.S. supply and demand but globally -- we're
going to get another look at this in the January

41.text:
crop report that is coming too -- globally
there is large stockpiles of cotton, in China

46.text:
particularly that at any point in time they
could wake up one morning and release these

50.text:
stockpiles and really drive prices down. So
that is the kind of market where you would

56.text:
not want to face that risk or you might be
looking ahead, even as a speculation, and

60.text:
thinking that it might make sense to get short
in cotton.

62.text:
Pearson: Now, we were talking a couple of
weeks ago about China's large stockpile and

68.text:
at that point there were concerns about the
quality of the cotton that China had been

71.text:
stockpiling. Is that still an issue? Is the
market still concerned about what it is that

76.text:
Kub: It may be. The merchandisers of cotton,
they may have been getting their hands on

81.text:
or certainly contracting down the higher quality
cotton in the U.S. and, again, that may have

86.text:
been what drove this recent short-term higher
trend. But at some point, you know, I think

92.text:
you still have the threat of China releasing
those stockpiles and shocking the market.

95.text:
Pearson: Now, what happens when China, should
China release those stockpiles, where could

101.text:
Kub: Well, I think they would certainly drop
below 80 cents again fairly quickly. I don't

106.text:
know exactly where they would find support
again. It may not be a long-term trend that

111.text:
keeps going down and down and I don't know
that we'd go retest the previous lows from

116.text:
Pearson: Okay. But potential sub 80 and into
the 70s?

120.text:
Pearson: Alright. Well, now anything there
specifically? That would be your sort of trade

125.text:
of the week then as we look at cotton, get
short?

126.text:
Kub: Yes, I think so. And like I said, even
as a speculation I think it would make sense.

130.text:
I don't know that there are much reasons to
expect it to go back above 85 cents. I don't

135.text:
know that anyone really expected it to get
this far to begin with. So for it to -- to

139.text:
be short in cotton and see it take a dive
back down to low 80 that would be a nice little

144.text:
Pearson: Yes it would for those that are short
cotton. You bet. Now, we've got a question

148.text:
from John in Columbia, Missouri and we're
going to have you gaze into your crystal ball

152.text:
here. Look out to 2014 and John is curious,
can any ag product rally this year? And what

159.text:
will it take? We're seeing one going on with
fat cattle trade. What else out there looks

164.text:
Kub: Well, to answer his first question, can
any ag commodity -- yes, of course. Of course

168.text:
they can. Anything can happen. And, like I
said earlier in the show, that was the sort

174.text:
of thing that we were looking at in soybeans
even when it was a little bit dry in Brazil

177.text:
and quite a bit dry in Argentina. You look
for any sort of weather thing and you could

182.text:
easily see something have a major rally. But
that is not happening anymore in South America.

187.text:
I think that shipped has sailed. Their pods
are filling fine. They have plentiful moisture

191.text:
in the forecast, even the long range forecast
that will get them started into harvest, if

195.text:
anything they may be a little uncomfortably
wet during harvest. So for our major row crop

200.text:
ag commodities I don't see anything in the
near next few months that is going to trigger

206.text:
a rally. But we've still got the North American
crop to get through. We have no idea what

210.text:
the spring and summer weather is going to
be like. So within the year, to answer his

214.text:
question, of course they can. But that is
what it would take in my opinion to be some

218.text:
sort of weather effect or to go back to the
livestock or other commodities some sort of

225.text:
really juiced up demand. Like I mentioned,
crude oil was not able to go above $100 per

230.text:
barrel just because the economy is not growing
that fast, it's not that optimistic. But if

234.text:
something did happen that we really had a
lot of optimism and a lot of growth in the

238.text:
U.S. economy or the global economy that could
certainly help the boxed beef market and the

244.text:
fat cattle market and the feeder cattle market
and the hogs and all of the meats, sort of

248.text:
consumer demand could drive them. That's what
it would take to drive them to even higher

252.text:
Pearson: Alright. So there's a lot of potential
out there in a new year as there often is.

257.text:
And you mentioned the row crops, waiting on
a weather event, March of 2012, April of 2012

263.text:
we were all counting on huge planted acreage,
huge corn crop --

267.text:
Kub: 14 billion bushel crop, which we may
finally get.

269.text:
Pearson: Right, and we'll find out on the
10th. Now, Phil in Canada has a question.

273.text:
We're going to bring it back to wheat. We
talked about that a little bit on the show.

276.text:
Phil is curious, is there hope for wheat looking
out longer term? Or are world feed grain supplies

282.text:
just too onerous for the next two years barring
a weather calamity?

286.text:
Kub: I think there is hope for wheat in that
eventually we will spur some demand. We'll

292.text:
have somebody step in here and change that
trend. Trends change eventually. They cannot

296.text:
go on forever. Someone will come in and buy
that wheat. But as far as any bullish news

302.text:
items that I can see coming down the pipeline,
not really. So Australia is starting their

309.text:
harvest, getting pretty hot right now, so
USDA is going to look in on that and, again,

313.text:
possibly change that. They upped the Australian
production in the December report, they certainly

317.text:
may do so again in January based on favorable
harvests there. So there's not, like I mentioned,

324.text:
as I'm sure Phil knows, you know, Canada has
ample amounts of wheat so there's really not

329.text:
a lot, other than demand, other than export
demand, buying, again, consumer demand, consumer

334.text:
change in pattern, diets changing, that is
what it would take to change that trend in

338.text:
Pearson: Right. So we're going to need to
see the economies continue to improve around

341.text:
the world to get consumer demand up and then
probably prices stay low a little while to

347.text: chew through the stockpile we've got.

350.text:
Pearson: Alright. Now, we've got a couple
of questions, guys curious about corn. Bob

353.text:
in Nebraska is asking -- and we touched on
this on the show but maybe you can go into

357.text:
a little bit more detail -- Bob says, for
those of us still holding onto 2013 corn what

362.text:
do you feel about the chances we will see
an increase in the corn cash price in the

366.text:
month of January when compared to cash harvest
prices we could have received. Do current

372.text:
prices already reflect a worse case January
crop report?

377.text:
Kub: No. I think that the chances for cash
corn prices going up within January are fairly

386.text:
slim. This is just typically the time of year
when farmers may be selling or the commercial

392.text:
mills and consumers are still working through
the harvest stockpiles. So this is not the

397.text:
time of year where you would ever typically
expect to see a rally in cash corn prices.

403.text:
And as far as a worst case scenario I think
that yes, I think that the size of the harvest

408.text:
and the size of demand is pretty well priced
in at this point. But a worst case scenario

413.text:
January crop report could be quite wild indeed
and we could easily see that average cash

418.text:
corn price in the country fall well below
$4.00 or 20 cents below $4.00 let's say. That

423.text:
could happen on a really volatile crop report,
worst case scenario. But I think that the

430.text:
market is pretty well priced in the anticipation
of a 14 billion bushel number from the USDA

436.text:
and hopefully nobody will be too surprised
by that when this comes out.

439.text:
Pearson: There's bearish sentiments already
in the price but --

443.text: Kub: Maybe not worst case scenario.

444.text:
Pearson: Certainly. That would be a great
buying opportunity if we already were pricing

449.text:
Pearson: You bet. Alright. Well, Elaine, we
really thank you for being with us. Before

452.text:
we let you go, any final thoughts on the market
here in this next week or this next month?

456.text: Anything that really jumps out at you?

458.text:
Kub: Well, I think that, you know, I'm jittery
like the stock investors that we would see

463.text:
something really wild happen there. I feel
like it was probably overwrought there at

467.text:
the end of 2013 going after that record high
and everybody is waiting to see if there's

471.text:
going to be a major pullback, even 20% and
I don't ordinarily, I don't ordinarily do

477.text:
much analysis of stocks but the concern is
that an event like that would really scare

481.text:
investors and create volatility, waves of
volatility through a lot of other investment

487.text:
Pearson: And then we would see that in the
farm yard.

490.text:
Pearson: Alright. Well thank you so much for
being with us, Elaine, appreciate you taking

494.text:
Pearson: And thanks to all of you for sending
in your questions via Facebook and Twitter.

498.text:
Please continue to do so and we'll continue
to get expert analysis right to you. Thanks

502.text: for watching and have a great week.
